p: Epidemics/epizootics of humans and domestic animals usually occur when the enzootic virus is introduced into rural environments or comes to close contact with humans by a bridge vector ( Fig. 2). Usually, humans and domestic animals develop clinical disease but do not develop a sufficient level of viremia to infect arthropods, thus, they are considered dead-end hosts and do not contribute to the transmission cycle [ 15, 16]. However, some arboviruses such as dengue fever (DF), yellow fever, and chikungunya (CHIKV) viruses cause high levels of viremia in humans and can be transmitted from person to person by mosquitoes (urban cycle) ( Fig. 2) [ 17].
